results.headline: Death of an Art House Means a Start to a Life
results.summary_short: In Federico Veiroj’s film “A Useful Life” the programmer of a failing art house faces a challenge to his hermetic existence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Useful Life

results.headline: Raw View of African Cure for Addiction to Drugs
results.summary_short: The documentary filmmaker Michel Negroponte’s case for ibogaine, a hallucinogenic powder made from an African plant, as a remedy for drug addiction is arresting but inconclusive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm Dangerous with Love

results.headline: An Indian Murder Reverberates on Film
results.summary_short: “No One Killed Jessica,” a film by Raj Kumar Gupta, revisits a notorious murder case in India.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No One Killed Jessica

results.headline: A Bar Where Everybody Knows Your Pole Dance
results.summary_short: In Abel Ferrara’s “Go Go Tales,” a Manhattan strip club owned by Willem Dafoe and run by Bob Hoskins faces eviction by Sylvia Miles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Go Go Tales

results.headline: In Nazareth, Human Comedy as Wind Rustles the Olive Branches
results.summary_short: In Elia Suleiman’s film “The Time That Remains,” a son views his father’s life and experiences in the first Arab-Israeli war.
results.display_title: The Time That Remains: Chronicles of a Present Absentee

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Time That Remains: Chronicles of a Present Absentee

results.headline: Deserters From the Crusades
results.summary_short: “Season of the Witch” is a 14th-century road movie with 21st-century cuss words.

results.headline: I Am Woman. Hear Me Sob, Y’All.
results.summary_short: Gwyneth Paltrow plays an alcoholic country-western star in Shana Feste’s new film, “Country Strong.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Country Strong

results.headline: Freedom Is No Guarantee for a Happily Ever After
results.summary_short: In “If I Want to Whistle, I Whistle,” Romania’s official submission for the best foreign language film Oscar, the protagonist is released from jail but has few prospects.

results.headline: In Remote Corner of Portugal, a Photographer Finds More Than He Expects
results.summary_short: A new feature from the 102-year-old Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira takes place in the Douro Valley of northern Portugal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Strange Case of Angelica

results.headline: Injustice, British and Otherwise
results.summary_short: Mike Leigh’s “Another Year,” like many of his films, is about the casualties of British class consciousness. But it also trains its eye on another form of unfairness: the unequal distribution of happiness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Another Year

results.headline: Young Math Wizard Stumbles Upon Oz, Deep in the Heart of the Internet
results.summary_short: In Mamoru Hosoda’s anime feature “Summer Wars,” Oz is a global virtual reality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sama Wozu

results.headline: A Fake Danish Comedy Troupe Goes To North Korea, With Strange Results
results.summary_short: In “The Red Chapel,” a Danish journalist sets out to punk North Korea by arranging to visit it with two Danish-Korean comedians.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Red Chapel

results.headline: Chronicling Love’s Fade to Black
results.summary_short: “Blue Valentine,” starring Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, plays on time in examining love lost and found.

results.headline: The Mob Work Is Tough; Then He Has to Go Home
results.summary_short: Javier Bardem plays an underworld figure stressed by work and family in Alejandro González Iñárritu’s “Biutiful.”

results.headline: From Bollywood: Making a Movie to Cover Up a Crime
results.summary_short: “Tees Maar Khan,” directed by Farah Khan, is about a thief who plots to steal some antique treasures.

results.headline: Conjuring a Magical Relationship
results.summary_short: The director Sylvain Chomet adapts a Jacques Tati screenplay in “The Illusionist,” about the friendship between a struggling magician and a teenage girl.

results.headline: Extremist in Monastery Is Still One Outside It
results.summary_short: Bruno Dumont’s austere, grimly luminous film “Hadewijch” follows a young woman from a convent to the projects of Paris, where she learns about Islam.

results.headline: A Gut Visible All the Way From the 18th Century
results.summary_short: Jonathan Swift takes a long trek to assess the modern cinematic take on his most famous creation.

results.headline: Fierce Tests of Endurance and the Resilience of the Spirit
results.summary_short: Lee Chang-dong is attentive to the routines and rhythms of everyday life in “Secret Sunshine.” But there is nothing ordinary about this movie, or about the story it tells.

results.headline: Wearing Braids, Seeking Revenge
results.summary_short: The Coen brothers’ remake of “True Grit” brings Rooster Cogburn and his brutish world back to a tougher Mattie Ross.
